title: Download and upload container images to a registry
content:
Before you deploy the suite, you need to download the images from the official Docker Hub to a your registry. In the current release we use Artifactory registry to host images on GCP.

Prepare the registry

Complete the following steps to prepare the Artifactory registry for storing images.

  1. Make sure you already enabled Artifactory Registry API. For details, see Google's official documentation Enable an API.
  2. Run the following command to know your cluster's service account information.You will need it the later steps. 
    gcloud config get-value account
    The command output may resemble the following: 878xxxxx026-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com.
  3. Follow the official documentation to set up the Artifactory registry. Make sure you choose Access token for the authentication method. For details on setting up your Artifactory registry see, Store Docker container images in Artifact Registry. For details on enabling Access token for authenticaiton, see Access token.
  4. Run the following command to get a auth token and verify that the authentication is setup correctly. Use this command to get access tokens to upload images to the Artifactory registry. 
    gcloud auth print-access-token --impersonate-service-account <your service account>

Generate the image set

Complete the following steps to generate download bundle for helm based installations.

  1. Log on to the bastion and then navigate to the $CDF_HOME/tools/generate-download directory.
  2. Run the generate_download_bundle.sh command together with the options required by your deployment. For the full list of command options, run the command with the -h option. 
    generate_download_bundle.sh -f <image_set_file> [ -d <output_directory>]
    Where:
    • <image_set_file>: The absolute path to the image set file. To locate this file, untar the esm-1.0.0+2x.x-xxx.tar  and check the scripts folder. 
    • <output_directory>: The directory where the script saves the offline-download.zip file. If you don't specify a value, the script saves the file to the default directory, which is the current working directory.
    For example: 
    generate_download_bundle.sh -f  <ESM_Helm_Chart-2x.x.x>/scripts/image_sets/_image-set.json -d /tmp
  3. When the offline-download.zip file is sucessfully generated, you will see a success message similar to the following: 
    INFO offline-download.zip is generated under /tmp
INFO For more details, please refer: /home/centos/cdf/log/generate_download_bundle/generate_download_bundle.20240129084204.log

The generated file contains the image download bundle. This bundle downloads the images required for installation.

Download the required installation images

  1. Log on to the first bastion node. If the bastion node can't access Docker Hub, transfer the  offline-download.zip  file to a Linux server that can access Docker Hub.
  2. Extract the .zip package to a directory. If you can't access Docker Hub directly, set up the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. For example, run the following commands to set the HTTP/HTTPS proxy. Replace the placeholders with your actual server and port. 
    export http_proxy="<http://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
export https_proxy="<https://PROXY_SERVER:PORT>"
  3. Go to the directory you extracted the offline-download.zip package, and run the following command: 
    ./downloadimages.sh [-u <username>] [-p <password>] [-d <image download directory>] [-c <digital signature verification>] [-o <org name>]
    Where:
    • <username> and <password>: The Docker Hub username and password.  If you don't pass the credentials to the command, you will be prompted for them during execution.
    • <image download directory>: The directory where the container images will be downloaded. The default is /var/opt/cdf/offline.
    • <digital signature verification>: Verifies the digital signature of the images during the download. The default is off, which doesn't verify the signature. Set it to on to allow signature verification.
    • <org name>: The organization in the image registry that contains the images for installation. The default is hpeswitom. This option is mandatory if you aren't using the default organization name.
    To see the full list of options for the downloadimages.sh command, run the following command: 
    ./downloadimages.sh –h
     

    The ./downloadimages.sh command also has a -p option to provide your password. The -p  option doesn't support single quotes (that is, don't include single quotes in the password.

    By selecting the -p option, you are disabling or bypassing security features, thereby exposing the system to increased security risks. By using this option, you understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same.

    OpenText encourages you to use some other password options, which aren't provided by Micro Focus. By implementing the -p option, you may expose the system to increased security risks. (Optional) Transfer the images to the bastion node

If you downloaded the images to a server other than the bastion node, transfer the images to a directory on the bastion node. By default, the images should be placed under the /var/opt/cdf/offline directory.

The images will be uploaded using the uploadimages.sh script in the next step. The image upload requires a storage space up to 2 times of the image size in the target image directory. For example, if you choose to use the default /var/opt/cdf/offline directory, and your image size is 10 GB, make sure that you have 20 GB or more free storage space under /var/opt/cdf/offline directory of the bastion node.

Upload the images

Follow these steps to upload the installation images to your image registry:

  1. Log on to one of the bastion nodes. The node must be able to connect to the registry.
  2. Run the following command to get the authentication token, use the verified service account in previous Prepare the registry step: 
    gcrpwd=$(gcloud auth print-access-token --impersonate-service-account 878xxxxx026-compute@developer.gserviceaccount.com 2> /dev/null)
echo  $gcrpwd
  3. Go to the directory you extracted the offline-download.zip package.
  4. Run the following command to upload the suite images to the registry: 
    ./uploadimages.sh -r <registry> -u <username> -p <password> -d <image download directory> -o <org name> -F <image-set file> -k <chunksize>
    Where:
    • <registry> is the URL of the registry.
    • <username> and <password> are the user name and password of your docker registry. You can get it from the admin of the registry.
    • <image download directory> is the directory to which you downloaded the container images. The default value is /var/opt/cdf/offline. Specify the -d option if the images aren't in the /var/opt/cdf/offline/ directory. You can use the -d option multiple times when the images are in different directories. The images can be the images downloaded using the downloadimages.sh script. Make sure the image file type matches the file extension. 
    • <org name> is the organization in the image registry that contains the images for installation. By default, this is hpeswitom. This option is mandatory if you aren't using the default organization name.
    • <image-set file>: Path to the file containing the image set. 
    • <chunksize>: Chunking size for image transfer. Default value is 100000000000.
    For example: 
    uploadimages.sh -r 'us-west2-docker.pkg.dev' -u oauth2accesstoken -p $gcrpwd -d esmImages/ -o 'itom-smax-nonprod/esm' -F ./image-set.json -k 100000000000
  5. To see the full list of options for the uploadimages.sh script, run the following command: 
    ./uploadimages.sh -h
  6. Wait until the images are successfully uploaded. You will see a success message on terminal similar to the following: 
    Upload-process successfully completed.
